output.conclusion: This course provides a comprehensive understanding of power systems, equipping you with the knowledge and skills to analyze, design, and operate modern power grids effectively.
output.introduction: Welcome to Advanced Power Systems! This course delves into the intricacies of modern power grids, covering advanced topics in power system analysis, control, and protection. We will explore the challenges and opportunities presented by renewable energy integration, smart grids, and emerging technologies.

chapters.description: Representation of power system components (generators, transformers, transmission lines, loads) using equivalent circuit models. Per-unit system and its advantages. Network matrices (Ybus, Zbus) formulation.
Newton-Raphson and Gauss-Seidel methods for solving power flow equations. PV and PQ buses. Convergence criteria. Load flow studies for different operating conditions.
Calculation of fault currents and voltages during balanced three-phase faults. Thevenin's theorem application. Short-circuit capacity and its impact on equipment selection.
Symmetrical components (positive, negative, and zero sequence). Sequence networks for different types of unsymmetrical faults (SLG, LL, LLG). Fault current calculation using sequence networks.
Classification of power system stability (transient, dynamic, voltage). Swing equation and its application to transient stability analysis. Equal area criterion.
Voltage collapse phenomenon. P-V and Q-V curves. Voltage stability margins. Methods for improving voltage stability.
Principles of power system protection. Overcurrent, distance, and differential relays. Protection of generators, transformers, and transmission lines.
Adaptive relaying schemes for improved protection performance. Wide-area measurement systems (WAMS) based protection.
Automatic generation control (AGC). Load frequency control (LFC). Voltage control techniques. Reactive power management.
Flexible AC transmission systems (FACTS) devices. Static VAR compensators (SVC), thyristor-controlled series compensators (TCSC), and unified power flow controllers (UPFC).
Smart grid concepts and technologies. Advanced metering infrastructure (AMI). Demand response. Wide area monitoring, protection and control (WAMPAC).
Impact of renewable energy sources (wind, solar) on power system operation and stability. Grid integration challenges and solutions. Microgrids.
